information:
As of mid-May 2025, New York Yankees player Aaron Judge's batting average was reported at various points between .402 and .423. On May 17, after a 2-for-4 game, his average reached .414, though a subsequent 0-for-5 game lowered it. By May 18, Judge had accumulated 15 home runs and 41 RBI for the season, leading the league in several offensive categories. An analysis by MLB.com noted that achieving a .414 batting average with over 15 home runs within a team's first 44 games is a rare historical feat, with parallels to seasons by Mickey Mantle in 1956 and Manny Ramirez in 2001.

According to a list of National League batting leaders published on May 18, 2025, Freddie Freeman of the Los Angeles Dodgers was leading with a .375 average. Other top hitters included Will Smith (Los Angeles Dodgers) at .336, Brendan Donovan (St. Louis Cardinals) at .330, and Manny Machado (San Diego Padres) at .323. In the American League, David Alonso of the New York Mets had a team-high batting average of .308 as of May 17. In Triple-A, Chicago Cubs prospect Matt Shaw was reported to be hitting .400 over his last eight games.

The last Major League Baseball player to finish a season with a batting average of .400 or higher was Ted Williams, who hit .406 in 1941. One analysis noted that modern players face challenges in reaching this mark, such as higher strikeout rates; early in the 2025 season, Aaron Judge had 31 strikeouts, whereas Williams had only 27 in his entire 1941 season. Another factor is Batting Average on Balls In Play (BABIP). The major league-wide BABIP in 2025 is .288, compared to .300 in 1930. In 2000, Ichiro Suzuki recorded a .387 batting average but was limited to 105 games due to an injury.

forecast.time_left_until_outcome_known: Approximately 13 days, as the question resolves on June 1, 2025.
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: Aaron Judge's batting average, currently hovering around .400, experiences a natural regression over the final two weeks of May. A few average games (e.g., 1-for-4) or a minor slump are enough to pull his average below the .400 threshold by June 1st. No other player manages to go on a sustained hot streak required to reach that mark.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: Aaron Judge continues his exceptional performance through the end of May, avoiding any prolonged slumps. He manages to get enough multi-hit games to counteract the inevitable hitless games, and his batting average on balls in play (BABIP) remains high, allowing him to be at or above .400 on June 1, 2025.
forecast.rationale:
My forecast is centered on the current performance of New York Yankees player Aaron Judge. The probability is significantly elevated from the historical base rate because, as of mid-May, Judge has actively maintained an average at or above .400. This is not a theoretical possibility; we have a specific player demonstrating the required level of performance, which is the primary evidence for the 'Yes' case.

However, I am forecasting 'No' as the more likely outcome, with a 60% probability. The primary factor supporting this is the strong statistical principle of regression to the mean. Maintaining a .400 batting average is incredibly difficult and fragile. A single 0-for-5 game, as noted in the research, can significantly lower the average. Over the next ~13 days, Judge will have approximately 40-50 at-bats. To maintain a .400 average, he must continue to perform at a historically elite level. Any return to 'normal' or even 'very good' performance (e.g., hitting .300-.350 over that stretch) will pull his overall average below .400. The historical context, with no player finishing a season at .400 since 1941, and modern factors like higher strikeout rates, underscore this difficulty, even for a period as short as two months.

My forecast is not lower than 40% because Judge has already sustained this level for nearly two months, proving it is possible for him over a significant sample size. The remaining time frame is short, so a continuation of his hot streak is plausible. My forecast is not higher than 40% because the statistical forces working against him are immense. The odds of any player avoiding even a minor slump over a two-week period are low, and for a player performing at such an extreme outlier level, the pull of regression is exceptionally strong.

I would increase my probability if Judge were to have several multi-hit games in the next week, pushing his average to the .420s and creating a buffer. Conversely, I would decrease my probability if he has a few sub-par games that drop his average below .400 before the final week of May.
